tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving torsion of a thin-walled beam. It requires using the formula for angle of twist per unit length, which involves multiple steps including calculating the area enclosed by the mid-line of the section. The image is essential for determining the geometry.

answer_validation.reasoning: The beam is a thin-walled closed rectangular section of constant thickness. For thin-walled closed sections, torsional stiffness is given by $T = 4 A_m^2 G t^{-1} \frac{d\theta}{dz}$, where $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the median line and $t$ is wall thickness (constant here). From the figure: width $b = 400\,\text{mm}$, height $h = 100\,\text{mm}$, thickness $t = 2\,\text{mm}$. For thin walls, the median-line dimensions are $b_m = b - t = 398\,\text{mm}$ and $h_m = h - t = 98\,\text{mm}$, so $A_m = b_m h_m = 3.9004 \times 10^4\,\text{mm}^2$. Using $T = 3.2\,\text{kNm} = 3.2 \times 10^6\,\text{Nmm}$ and $G = 25\,\text{GPa} = 25 \times 10^3\,\text{N/mm}^2$, the twist rate is $\frac{d\theta}{dz} = \dfrac{T t}{4 A_m^2 G}$. Substituting gives $\frac{d\theta}{dz} \approx 9.0 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{rad/mm} = 9.0 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{rad/m}$ (after unit conversion), which rounds to $0.009$–$0.010$ rad/m, matching the official range 0.009 to 0.011 rad/m. Small differences arise from whether one uses outer dimensions or median-line dimensions, but all give a value within the accepted range.

step_by_step: Step 1: Identify the section as a thin-walled closed rectangular tube of constant thickness $t = 2\,\text{mm}$, with outer dimensions $400\,\text{mm}$ by $100\,\text{mm}$, subjected to torque $T = 3.2\,\text{kNm}$ and shear modulus $G = 25\,\text{GPa}$.

Step 2: For a thin-walled closed section of constant thickness, use the torsion relation $T = 4 A_m^2 G \dfrac{d\theta}{dz} \dfrac{1}{\int (ds/t)}$. With constant $t$, this simplifies to $T = 4 A_m^2 G \dfrac{d\theta}{dz} \dfrac{1}{(L_m/t)} = 4 A_m^2 G t^{-1} \dfrac{d\theta}{dz}$, where $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the median line and $L_m$ its perimeter.
Step 3: Compute the median-line dimensions: $b_m = 400 - t = 398\,\text{mm}$ and $h_m = 100 - t = 98\,\text{mm}$. Then $A_m = b_m h_m = 398 \times 98\,\text{mm}^2 = 3.9004 \times 10^4\,\text{mm}^2$.

Step 4: Rearrange the torsion formula to get the twist rate: $\dfrac{d\theta}{dz} = \dfrac{T t}{4 A_m^2 G}$. Convert given quantities to consistent units: $T = 3.2 \times 10^6\,\text{Nmm}$, $t = 2\,\text{mm}$, $G = 25 \times 10^3\,\text{N/mm}^2$.

Step 5: Substitute: $\dfrac{d\theta}{dz} = \dfrac{3.2 \times 10^6 \times 2}{4 (3.9004 \times 10^4)^2 (25 \times 10^3)}\,\text{rad/mm}$. Evaluate the denominator and simplify numerically to obtain $\dfrac{d\theta}{dz} \approx 9.0 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{rad/mm}$.

Step 6: Convert rad/mm to rad/m by multiplying by $10^3$: $\dfrac{d\theta}{dz} \approx 9.0 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{rad/m}$. Rounding to three decimal places gives approximately $0.009$–$0.010\,\text{rad/m}$, which lies within the official answer range.

topic.name: Torsion of thin-walled closed sections
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 2: Structures -> Bending, Shear and Torsion of Beams

concepts.name: Angle of twist per unit length

essential: Basic torsion theory for circular shafts ($T = GJ \frac{d\theta}{dz}$)
Concept of shear modulus $G$ and its units
Thin-walled approximation and median-line area for closed sections
Unit consistency and conversion between mm and m
helpful: Derivation of torsion constant for thin-walled closed sections
Understanding of shear flow in thin-walled beams

Main Concept: requires: Definition of torsion constant $J$ for thin-walled closed sections
enables: Design of torsion boxes in aircraft wings and fuselage
enables: Advanced analysis including multi-cell torsion and warping

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling the specific torsion constant formula for thin-walled closed sections
Careful unit conversion from mm to m and kNm to Nmm is needed

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Combined Open and Closed Section Beams / Torsion of Closed Sections
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a thin-walled closed section of constant thickness, the torsion constant is $J = 4A_m^2/\int (ds/t)$ and the torque-twist relation is $T = GJ\,d\theta/dz$.

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: The total applied torque is related to the shear flow in a closed thin-walled section by $T = 2Aq$ for each cell, leading to expressions for torsional rigidity.

video_references.topic_covered: Angle of twist in shafts and dependence on $T, L, G, J$
Torsional stiffness and maximum shear stress in circular shafts

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Recognize thin-walled closed section \u2192 Use torsion constant formula \u2192 Compute median-line area \u2192 Apply torque-twist relation \u2192 Evaluate numerically \u2192 Convert units and round
key_insights: For thin-walled closed sections, torsional rigidity depends on the square of the enclosed median-line area.
Using median-line dimensions instead of outer dimensions gives a slightly more accurate torsion constant, but both lead to answers within the accepted range.
Consistent units (N, mm or N, m) are crucial when using $G$ in GPa and dimensions in mm.

formulas_principles.name: Basic torsion relation
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to prismatic members under uniform torque with linear elastic behavior.
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation linking torque, torsion constant, shear modulus, and twist rate.

formulas_principles.name: Torsion constant for thin-walled closed section
formulas_principles.conditions: Thin-walled closed section, shear flow approximately uniform through thickness.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute torsional rigidity of the rectangular tube.

formulas_principles.name: Median-line area of rectangle
formulas_principles.conditions: Rectangular thin-walled closed section with median-line dimensions $b_m$ and $h_m$.
formulas_principles.relevance: Provides the enclosed area needed for the torsion constant.

formulas_principles.name: Twist rate for thin-walled rectangular tube
formulas_principles.conditions: Rectangular thin-walled closed section of constant thickness.
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly used to compute the required angle of twist per unit length.

industry_examples: Design of wing torsion boxes in aircraft, where thin-walled closed sections carry aerodynamic torque.
Torsion analysis of fuselage frames and tail booms, which often use rectangular or multi-cell thin-walled sections.
specific_systems: Main wing torque box of a transport aircraft, modeled as a multi-cell thin-walled closed section.
Tail boom of a helicopter, which must resist torsion from tail rotor thrust.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate prediction of twist in thin-walled closed sections is essential to ensure aeroelastic stability, control effectiveness, and structural integrity under torsional loads.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the solid-rectangle torsion constant formula instead of the thin-walled closed-section formula.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall the more familiar solid-section formulas from basic strength of materials and overlook the thin-walled assumption.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Whenever thickness is small compared to other dimensions and the section is closed, explicitly recall the thin-walled closed-section torsion formulas.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a much smaller torsion constant and a twist rate that is orders of magnitude too large.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to convert torque from kNm to Nmm or N\u00b7m consistently with $G$ and dimensions.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They rush through unit conversions or mix mm and m in the same calculation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Before calculation, choose either N-mm or N-m system and convert all quantities (T, dimensions, G) accordingly.
common_mistakes.consequence: Produces answers off by factors of 10^3 or 10^6, clearly outside the expected range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using outer dimensions directly for $A_m$ without considering the median line.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They are not fully aware that the area in the formula is the median-line area, not the outer area.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that in thin-walled theory, all geometric integrals are taken along the mid-surface (median line). Subtract one thickness from each overall dimension to get median-line dimensions.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives a slightly different numerical value, but usually still within the acceptable exam tolerance.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not recognizing that the question asks for angle of twist per unit length and instead computing total twist for an assumed length.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They are used to problems specifying a shaft length and automatically multiply by L.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline phrases like 'per unit length' in the question and keep $d\theta/dz$ as the final quantity.
common_mistakes.consequence: Answer is off by a factor equal to the (incorrectly assumed) length.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: For thin WALLed closed sections: "Area squared over Wall Length" gives J.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when deciding which torsion constant formula to apply for closed thin-walled beams.

flashcards.front: What is the torsion constant $J$ for a thin-walled closed section of median-line area $A_m$ and thickness $t(s)$?
flashcards.back: For a thin-walled closed section, $J = \dfrac{4 A_m^2}{\int (ds/t)}$. If thickness is constant, $J = \dfrac{4 A_m^2 t}{L_m}$ where $L_m$ is the median-line perimeter.

flashcards.front: In torsion of thin-walled closed sections, what does $A_m$ represent?
flashcards.back: $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the median line (mid-surface) of the wall, not the outer or inner area.

flashcards.front: A thin-walled rectangular tube (400 mm x 100 mm, t = 2 mm) is under torque T. Which formula relates T and twist rate $d\theta/dz$?
flashcards.back: Use $T = GJ\,d\theta/dz$ with $J = 4A_m^2/\int (ds/t)$. For constant t, $\dfrac{d\theta}{dz} = \dfrac{T t}{4 A_m^2 G}$.

flashcards.front: What unit checks should you perform when using $G = 25$ GPa and dimensions in mm?
flashcards.back: Convert $G$ to $25 \times 10^3$ N/mm^2 and torque to Nmm, or convert all lengths to m and use $G$ in Pa. Never mix mm and m in the same formula.

real_world_context.application: Torsion of aircraft wing torque boxes under aerodynamic loads.
real_world_context.industry_example: A transport aircraft wing box, modeled as a multi-cell thin-walled closed section, must have limited twist under engine-out or gust loads to maintain control surface effectiveness.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating twist can lead to control reversal, flutter, or structural failure; overdesign increases weight and fuel consumption.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Identify it as a standard thin-walled closed-section torsion problem. If you recall $J = 4A_m^2/\int (ds/t)$, it becomes a quick plug-in calculation with simple arithmetic.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure of the exact formula, note that thin-walled closed sections are very stiff in torsion, so the twist per meter should be small (order of $10^{-2}$ rad/m, not 1 rad/m or more).
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2 minutes: 1 minute to recall and write the formula, 1 minute for arithmetic and unit conversion.

search_keywords: thin walled closed section torsion Megson
torsion constant J thin walled rectangular tube
angle of twist per unit length closed section beam
shear flow and torque in thin walled beams

alternative_methods.name: Shear flow approach using $T = 2Aq$
alternative_methods.description: Assume uniform shear flow $q$ around the thin-walled closed section. For a single-cell section, torque is $T = 2 A_m q$. Relate shear flow to shear strain via $q = t \tau$ and $\tau = G \gamma$. Using compatibility of twist, derive $d\theta/dz$ without explicitly using $J$.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Builds deeper understanding of shear flow and torsion in thin-walled structures; extends naturally to multi-cell sections. Cons: Longer derivation and more algebra, not ideal for a 1-mark exam question.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when studying theory or solving more complex multi-cell torsion problems where direct $J$ formulas are not readily available.

connections_to_other_subjects.Aerodynamics: Wing torsion interacts with aerodynamic lift distribution, leading to aeroelastic phenomena like divergence and control reversal.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Twist of lifting surfaces affects control derivatives and stability characteristics.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Structural flexibility (including torsion) can couple with control system dynamics, requiring careful modeling.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Satellite booms and solar arrays often use thin-walled tubes where torsional stiffness is critical for pointing accuracy.

deeper_dive_topics: Multi-cell torsion in thin-walled beams and distribution of shear flow between cells
Warping torsion effects in open versus closed thin-walled sections
Aeroelastic divergence of wings due to insufficient torsional stiffness
Optimization of wing box geometry for minimum weight and required torsional rigidity

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Bending, Shear and Torsion of Beams; Thin-walled Beams
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent alignment with the requirement to analyze torsion in thin-walled beams, a core topic for aerospace structural design.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general torsion relations ($T = GJ d\theta/dz$) and context on torsional stiffness, but did not explicitly give the thin-walled closed-section torsion constant formula. The detailed solution relied mainly on internal knowledge of thin-walled closed-section theory, with RAG used for supporting concepts and consistency checks.

future_questions_potential: Given a multi-cell thin-walled box beam with different wall thicknesses, determine the shear flow distribution and angle of twist under a specified torque.
For a thin-walled open section beam, compare the twist with that of a closed section of the same material and overall dimensions under the same torque.
Design a rectangular thin-walled torsion box with minimum weight subject to a maximum allowable twist per unit length.
Include warping constraints at the ends of an open thin-walled section and compute the resulting warping torsion and twist distribution.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A thin walled beam of constant thickness shown in the figure is subjected to a torque of 3.2 kNm. If the shear modulus is 25 GPa, the angle of twist per unit length is __________ rad/m (round off to three decimal places).
